content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays three separate pieces of tissue stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E). Their overall architecture, with a dense purple cellular component and a vaguely ovoid or lobulated shape, is characteristic of lymph nodes. They are surrounded by paler-staining adipose and connective tissue. My initial task would be to systematically examine each of these three lymph nodes for the presence of metastatic tumor cells.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this specific area on the largest, leftmost lymph node. The location is at the periphery of the node, at the interface between the lymphoid tissue, the lymph node capsule, and the surrounding perinodal fat. This is a critical region to scrutinize because metastatic carcinoma cells typically arrive in the lymph node via afferent lymphatic vessels and first deposit in the subcapsular sinus. Therefore, a thorough examination of the entire subcapsular sinus is essential to detect early metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I can clearly identify three components: dense lymphoid tissue (bottom left and right), mature adipose tissue (top), and the intervening lymph node capsule and subcapsular space (center). Within the fibrous capsule and extending into the surrounding fat, there are small, irregular nests and individual atypical cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and pleomorphic, vesicular nuclei. These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma with evidence of extranodal extension (tumor cells in the perinodal adipose tissue).
